texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The world of amateur, or ham, radio is huge and it's what you want to make of it. The itch struck me in the middle of 2017 and I learned a lot since then.
texts.text: The world of amateur, or ham, radio is huge and it's what you want to make of it. The itch struck me in the middle of 2017 and I learned a lot since then.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: People often ask me questions about all kinds of amateur radio topics and I decided to compile all of the answers into a big page that I can update over time. If your questions isn't answered here, please  send me an email  and I'll get it answered!
texts.text: People often ask me questions about all kinds of amateur radio topics and I decided to compile all of the answers into a big page that I can update over time. If your questions isn't answered here, please  send me an email  and I'll get it answered!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Keep in mind that the vast majority of the topics presented here will be applicable to amateur radio all over the world, but much of the discussion around licensing and rules is very specific to the United States.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: The very very basics {#basics}
texts.text: The very very basics {#basics}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This section covers the absolute basic questions around the hobby itself and why it can be interesting for many people.
texts.text: This section covers the absolute basic questions around the hobby itself and why it can be interesting for many people.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Amateur radio is like Citizen's Band (CB) radio, right?
texts.text: Amateur radio is like Citizen's Band (CB) radio, right?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is entirely valid question, but be forewarned -- it can cause some amateur radio operators to start fuming. It's like going to Barcelona and asking:  "So  Catalan  is basically just a Spanish dialect, right?"  😡
texts.text: This is entirely valid question, but be forewarned -- it can cause some amateur radio operators to start fuming. It's like going to Barcelona and asking:  "So  Catalan  is basically just a Spanish dialect, right?"  😡

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Author's note: Please don't try this in Barcelona.   I do not recommend it.
texts.text: Author's note: Please don't try this in Barcelona.   I do not recommend it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Yes, CB radios are similar in some ways. The are restricted to certain bands and you have a variety of radios to choose from if you want to talk to people.
texts.text: Yes, CB radios are similar in some ways. The are restricted to certain bands and you have a variety of radios to choose from if you want to talk to people.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, talking on a CB radio has very few restrictions and no licensing requirements. People often talk about topics that you wouldn't want your children to hear and many people willfully disobey what few rules and restrictions actually exist. Also, CB is only one band. Amateur radio has tons of bands to choose from based on the size of the radio you want to carry, how far you want to communicate, and your license level.
texts.text: However, talking on a CB radio has very few restrictions and no licensing requirements. People often talk about topics that you wouldn't want your children to hear and many people willfully disobey what few rules and restrictions actually exist. Also, CB is only one band. Amateur radio has tons of bands to choose from based on the size of the radio you want to carry, how far you want to communicate, and your license level.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Amateur radio offers tons of different operating modes, such as morse code, digital modes, meteor scatter, satellite operations, and plain old AM/FM/SSB voice communication. You can talk to someone on the other side of the Earth with amateur radio but CB radio range tops out at 20-25 miles.
texts.text: Amateur radio offers tons of different operating modes, such as morse code, digital modes, meteor scatter, satellite operations, and plain old AM/FM/SSB voice communication. You can talk to someone on the other side of the Earth with amateur radio but CB radio range tops out at 20-25 miles.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Long story short: they are tremendously different.
texts.text: Long story short: they are tremendously different.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: I have a mobile phone. Why do I need amateur radio?
texts.text: I have a mobile phone. Why do I need amateur radio?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This might not be the hobby for you, and that's okay!
texts.text: This might not be the hobby for you, and that's okay!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Keep in mind that mobile phones are just small radios that transmit and receive digital data all day long. If that interests you and you want to tinker on similar technologies, amateur radio might be good for you. Using a radio to call long distances (say, across the USA) on a frequent basis can be frustrating if you just need something that works all the time.
texts.text: Keep in mind that mobile phones are just small radios that transmit and receive digital data all day long. If that interests you and you want to tinker on similar technologies, amateur radio might be good for you. Using a radio to call long distances (say, across the USA) on a frequent basis can be frustrating if you just need something that works all the time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, consider those situations where mobile phones do not work, such as natural disasters. Communication falls back to radios during these difficult times and you may be able to assist with emergencies or get information for your family with some knowledge of amateur radio.
texts.text: However, consider those situations where mobile phones do not work, such as natural disasters. Communication falls back to radios during these difficult times and you may be able to assist with emergencies or get information for your family with some knowledge of amateur radio.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: I thought amateur radio was just for old people.
texts.text: I thought amateur radio was just for old people.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That's a common misconception, but there are many older people involved in amateur radio for a variety of reasons.
texts.text: That's a common misconception, but there are many older people involved in amateur radio for a variety of reasons.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Many military veterans had to work with radios during their miltary career and they find that amateur radio is a fun way to keep their skills sharp. It can also be a fun way to talk to other veterans on the radio and at club meetings.
texts.text: Many military veterans had to work with radios during their miltary career and they find that amateur radio is a fun way to keep their skills sharp. It can also be a fun way to talk to other veterans on the radio and at club meetings.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Amateur radio is something you can do even if you have physical limitations caused by injury, illness, or old age. Some hams have large towers with complex wiring and unique antennas. Others plop down a small vertical or magnetic loop on a desk and transmit from there.
texts.text: Amateur radio is something you can do even if you have physical limitations caused by injury, illness, or old age. Some hams have large towers with complex wiring and unique antennas. Others plop down a small vertical or magnetic loop on a desk and transmit from there.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's a great benefit to older folks being involved with amateur radio: they can teach you a lot . Often called  elmers  in ham radio vernacular, these are people who can prevent you from making costly mistakes in planning your station and they can show you some unique ways to fix radio problems. If you don't mind taking a little direction, many of these experienced hams will overwhelm you with radio knowledge that you can put to use immediately.
texts.text: There's a great benefit to older folks being involved with amateur radio: they can teach you a lot . Often called  elmers  in ham radio vernacular, these are people who can prevent you from making costly mistakes in planning your station and they can show you some unique ways to fix radio problems. If you don't mind taking a little direction, many of these experienced hams will overwhelm you with radio knowledge that you can put to use immediately.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With that said, there are plenty of younger people getting involved with ham radio. There are plenty of newer technologies, especially digital modes, that allow newer operators to mix over-the-air radio operations with functionality over the internet.
texts.text: With that said, there are plenty of younger people getting involved with ham radio. There are plenty of newer technologies, especially digital modes, that allow newer operators to mix over-the-air radio operations with functionality over the internet.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Can I just listen and see if it's interesting?
texts.text: Can I just listen and see if it's interesting?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Of course! In the United States, you can listen to any amateur radio transmission anytime with very inexpensive equipment. No licensing or expertise is required to listen.
texts.text: Of course! In the United States, you can listen to any amateur radio transmission anytime with very inexpensive equipment. No licensing or expertise is required to listen.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can pick up a shortwave radio and listen to long-distance transmissions, or you can buy a handheld transceiver (often called an  HT ) to listen to local discussions.
texts.text: You can pick up a shortwave radio and listen to long-distance transmissions, or you can buy a handheld transceiver (often called an  HT ) to listen to local discussions.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your local hams might have a repeater set up to rebroadcast local radio transmissions over a long distance. Head over to  RepeaterBook  to find your local repeaters and listen! I wrote a  lengthy post about repeaters  in 2018.
texts.text: Your local hams might have a repeater set up to rebroadcast local radio transmissions over a long distance. Head over to  RepeaterBook  to find your local repeaters and listen! I wrote a  lengthy post about repeaters  in 2018.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you want to go a bit further,  find your local radio club online  and go to one of their meetings! Tell them that you're new to the hobby and I'm sure they will be happy to show you some of their uses for radio. You might even discover a use that you never considered.
texts.text: If you want to go a bit further,  find your local radio club online  and go to one of their meetings! Tell them that you're new to the hobby and I'm sure they will be happy to show you some of their uses for radio. You might even discover a use that you never considered.

texts.orig: Getting a license {#license}
texts.text: Getting a license {#license}

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: I heard radio operators have license levels. What's in each level?
texts.text: I heard radio operators have license levels. What's in each level?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are three main licensing levels:
texts.text: There are three main licensing levels:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Technician

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You must pass a test to move up to the next level.
texts.text: You must pass a test to move up to the next level.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Technician gives you access to  lots  of frequencies, but the amount of things you can do below the 10 meter band is very limited. General opens the door to many of the frequencies below 10 meters, but Extra class licensees have the most access to those bands.
texts.text: Technician gives you access to  lots  of frequencies, but the amount of things you can do below the 10 meter band is very limited. General opens the door to many of the frequencies below 10 meters, but Extra class licensees have the most access to those bands.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: To learn more about what access each level gets, consult the  ARRL Band Plan or review the handy  graphical band chart   which is good for printing .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The great thing is that every single test (and its answers) is available to you online! Review the  question pools  at any time!
texts.text: The great thing is that every single test (and its answers) is available to you online! Review the  question pools  at any time!

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: How should I study for the test?
texts.text: How should I study for the test?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You have plenty of choices and hams will often argue which is best. 🤓
texts.text: You have plenty of choices and hams will often argue which is best. 🤓

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: HamStudy  is my go-to resource for studying and for reference after the exam. You can review content and take practice exams right on your computer for free. They also offer some mobile apps (for a fee, totally worth it) so you can study from wherever you are. Their site works well on Android devices right in the browser, so that may work for you as well.
texts.text: HamStudy  is my go-to resource for studying and for reference after the exam. You can review content and take practice exams right on your computer for free. They also offer some mobile apps (for a fee, totally worth it) so you can study from wherever you are. Their site works well on Android devices right in the browser, so that may work for you as well.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Another option is to get a book! The ARRL offers  study guides and reference material  for each license level. Some people learn better from offline books than electronic screens, and this could be the right option for you. Just be sure that the book you order matches the license level and the test currently being used. The tests are rotated out about every four years, so make sure the book is up to date.
texts.text: Another option is to get a book! The ARRL offers  study guides and reference material  for each license level. Some people learn better from offline books than electronic screens, and this could be the right option for you. Just be sure that the book you order matches the license level and the test currently being used. The tests are rotated out about every four years, so make sure the book is up to date.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You could also get the question and answer pools (see the previous question above) and go over all of those. This requires some brute force memorization and you may not learn the theory behind the questions.
texts.text: You could also get the question and answer pools (see the previous question above) and go over all of those. This requires some brute force memorization and you may not learn the theory behind the questions.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Keep in mind that rote memorization  will  get you past the test, but then you could make quite a few expensive or dangerous mistakes as you try to get on the air.
texts.text: Keep in mind that rote memorization  will  get you past the test, but then you could make quite a few expensive or dangerous mistakes as you try to get on the air.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Don't just try to beat the test. Learn the theory!  You will thank me later when you're trying to get your SWR in check on a dipole using the wrong feed line that has a high impedance. 🤦‍♂️
texts.text: Don't just try to beat the test. Learn the theory!  You will thank me later when you're trying to get your SWR in check on a dipole using the wrong feed line that has a high impedance. 🤦‍♂️

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Where do I go to take the test?
texts.text: Where do I go to take the test?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once again, ARRL has you covered. Fill in your location information and search for a test near you . In the San Antonio area, there are 3-4 testing locations that run tests on Saturdays. There's a test almost every weekend.
texts.text: Once again, ARRL has you covered. Fill in your location information and search for a test near you . In the San Antonio area, there are 3-4 testing locations that run tests on Saturdays. There's a test almost every weekend.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Keep in mind that some groups will only test if someone sends them a note to say they are coming to take a test. It requires a minimum of three volunteer examiners ( VEs ) to be present and they are exactly that -- volunteers! Most groups have an email address or phone number for you to contact if you want to take a test.
texts.text: Keep in mind that some groups will only test if someone sends them a note to say they are coming to take a test. It requires a minimum of three volunteer examiners ( VEs ) to be present and they are exactly that -- volunteers! Most groups have an email address or phone number for you to contact if you want to take a test.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be sure to note the fee for testing! It's usually $15, but it may be different in some places.
texts.text: Be sure to note the fee for testing! It's usually $15, but it may be different in some places.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're in the San Antonio, Texas area, I highly recommend  the ROOST . They are a friendly bunch of folks in a relaxed shack and they keep the examinees relaxed with plenty of jokes. You may spot a cat poke its head in the shack. I'm told that's a good omen. 😺

texts.text: It's test day! What do I bring?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you leave the house, you will need a FCC Registration Number ( FRN ) if you want things to go as smoothly as possible. Test results are submitted by hand on paper that goes through the postal mail. Yes, I know.
texts.text: Before you leave the house, you will need a FCC Registration Number ( FRN ) if you want things to go as smoothly as possible. Test results are submitted by hand on paper that goes through the postal mail. Yes, I know.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, the FCC has good documentation on  getting your FRN . By getting your FRN ahead of time, you will ensure that your test results are processed as quickly as humanly possible once they reach the FCC.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What should I expect when I take the exam?
texts.text: What should I expect when I take the exam?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most ham radio exams are extremely relaxed and the VEs are often very experienced radio operators who want more people to join the hobby. You are definitely with good people.
texts.text: Most ham radio exams are extremely relaxed and the VEs are often very experienced radio operators who want more people to join the hobby. You are definitely with good people.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you get signed in and you complete some paperwork (which includes your FRN, which I'm  sure  you brought with you), you will pay the testing fee. There are various versions of the test and you'll get one from the pile and sit down to take your test.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When everything is over and you pass at least one of the exams, the VEs will complete a form called the Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (or  CSCE ). Your CSCE is your record of passing the exam.  Put your copy in a safe place!  If it gets lost in the mail, you may need to provide that copy.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Choosing your first radio {#firstradio}
texts.text: Choosing your first radio {#firstradio}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Picking your first radio is an important first step towards learning the skills for your license or putting your new license to use! However, finding a new radio can be tricky.
texts.text: Picking your first radio is an important first step towards learning the skills for your license or putting your new license to use! However, finding a new radio can be tricky.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Radios come in all shapes and sizes. How do I choose?
texts.text: Radios come in all shapes and sizes. How do I choose?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First things first, you need to consider how and where you want to use your radio. That determines the type of radio you want to look for. For example:
texts.text: First things first, you need to consider how and where you want to use your radio. That determines the type of radio you want to look for. For example:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: At home: any radio, including handheld (HT), mobile, or base, should work
texts.text: At home: any radio, including handheld (HT), mobile, or base, should work

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In the car: go for a HT or a mobile radio
texts.text: In the car: go for a HT or a mobile radio

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: On you: HT for sure
texts.text: On you: HT for sure

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are benefits and drawbacks to each type of radio:
texts.text: There are benefits and drawbacks to each type of radio:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Base station radios.  These are typically radios that are meant to stay in one place and they may often be quite heavy or bulky. They usually have the largest feature set, highest power (usually 100-200W), and most connections (for extra antennas and accessories). Lugging these to the car or on a hike will be frustrating for most units unless you purchase a small one.
texts.text: Base station radios.  These are typically radios that are meant to stay in one place and they may often be quite heavy or bulky. They usually have the largest feature set, highest power (usually 100-200W), and most connections (for extra antennas and accessories). Lugging these to the car or on a hike will be frustrating for most units unless you purchase a small one.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Examples of base station radios I've used:

texts.text: [<RawText children='Icom 7300'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Mobile radios.  These are smaller than base station radios and they can be used at home or in the car. Many of these top out at 50W but they often have a good set of features. They often come with handy features like GPS (for APRS) or removable displays. Removable displays allow you to mount the radio in a hidden place (such as under your seat) and mount the display somewhere else in the car.
texts.text: Mobile radios.  These are smaller than base station radios and they can be used at home or in the car. Many of these top out at 50W but they often have a good set of features. They often come with handy features like GPS (for APRS) or removable displays. Removable displays allow you to mount the radio in a hidden place (such as under your seat) and mount the display somewhere else in the car.

texts.orig: I was told never to buy one of those Chinese clone radios. Why?
texts.text: I was told never to buy one of those Chinese clone radios. Why?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There is some truth and some myth here. Some of the manufacturers of really cheap radios, like Baofeng, are often ridiculed.
texts.text: There is some truth and some myth here. Some of the manufacturers of really cheap radios, like Baofeng, are often ridiculed.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sometimes it's for valid reasons, such as Baeofeng's  roger beep . That's a small tone made when you finish talking and let go of PTT. Amateur radio operators will often call you out for doing that and ask you to turn it off. You hear these beeps occasionally on commercial radios, especially trunked ones, but it has no place in amateur radio bands.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The FCC did recently publish  FCC Enforcement Advisotry DA 18-980  and they are cracking down on some imported radios that don't follow the most basic of FCC rules. Problems happen when unlicensed or licensed operators get one (really cheaply) and cause all kinds of problems on local radio repeaters during nets, emergencies, or other important events.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Baofengs will allow you to transmit on frequencies you shouldn't such as Family Radio Service (FRS)  or  General Mobile Radio Service (GMRS)  bands. It's illegal to use a radio that is not approved for those bands, and GMRS requires its own license that is entirely exclusive of the amateur radio license. (There's no test, but it costs $70 for 10 years of access.)

texts.orig: Radios are expensive! How can I afford this hobby?
texts.text: Radios are expensive! How can I afford this hobby?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are  many  ways to get a great radio at a price you can afford. You have two main options:
texts.text: There are  many  ways to get a great radio at a price you can afford. You have two main options:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Get something brand new.  There's nothing wrong with that! You will get the latest and greatest features in the smallest size with that new electronics smell. If you love that feeling of pulling plastic from screens and you don't want something anyone else has touched, this is a good option for you. However, there's a steep cost associated with it!

If you love that feeling of pulling plastic from screens and you don't want something anyone else has touched, this is a good option for you. However, there's a steep cost associated with it!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recommend shopping with  Main Trading Company  if you can. They're a small shop in Paris, Texas (not France), and they have a great selection. They've been really helpful for me when dealing with out of stock items.
texts.text: I recommend shopping with  Main Trading Company  if you can. They're a small shop in Paris, Texas (not France), and they have a great selection. They've been really helpful for me when dealing with out of stock items.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Get something used.  This is my favorite plan. Buying new is good, but you might skip on features to save price. A used radio might have all of the features you want, but it might also have some scratches and dings. Also, if the radio is fairly old (maybe 10+ years), someone has probably taken good care of it and it's a reliable rig.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My requirement is that I only buy radios from another radio operator. Most are trustworthy and they usually want you to understand the radio's capabilities before you buy.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are ham radio conventions of various sizes scattered around the USA each month and these usually have big swapmeets. Be prepared to see a lot of junk . This is stuff that won't power on, could barely be used for parts, and looks like it barely survived a nuclear war. Keep your eye out for the more well-maintained items there.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your local radio club meetings likely have a short section of the meeting dedicated to buy/sell/trade, so be sure to ask there. If you participate in a local radio net, perhaps on your local repeater, you can mention that you're looking for a radio. You might get recommendations for something to look for or you may get a lead on a good radio to buy! texts.orig: What does it mean when some radios say all-mode and others say FM?
texts.text: What does it mean when some radios say all-mode and others say FM?

This is really handy for mobile operations since you'll be using your voice most often there. However, this limits your fun on the high frequency bands.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Some radios cover all of the bands. Why doesn't everyone get those?
texts.text: Some radios cover all of the bands. Why doesn't everyone get those?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some  great  radios on the market, like the  Yaesu FT-991A  or the Icom 746  that pack tons of bands into one receiver. If you're looking for a "shack-in-a-box", then look no further! You can do everything with one radio.
texts.text: There are some  great  radios on the market, like the  Yaesu FT-991A  or the Icom 746  that pack tons of bands into one receiver. If you're looking for a "shack-in-a-box", then look no further! You can do everything with one radio.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some downsides to this, too. More electronics in the box increases weight and cost. It also increases the amount of things that can fail. In addition, a radio that tries to be good at many things sometimes can't be great on all of them. Jamming a 144 MHz (2 meter) transceiver into a crowded HF radio means compromises must be made somewhere.

In addition, a radio that tries to be good at many things sometimes can't be great on all of them. Jamming a 144 MHz (2 meter) transceiver into a crowded HF radio means compromises must be made somewhere.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are advantages to getting a radio that does a subset of HF, VHF and UHF bands. The manufacturer can specalize solely in those bands and make them perform really well. I haven't heard it myself, but many hams swear that radios that are dedicated to a subset of bands have better sound, better noise reduction, and better range.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Dedicated radios requires more radios to cover the bands you care about, and that means more expense. Also consider that you'll need more DC power for multiple radios and sharing antennas can be frustrating without additional equipment (and expense).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Everyone tells me digital modes are great. How do I get a radio for FT8?
texts.text: Everyone tells me digital modes are great. How do I get a radio for FT8?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Digital modes are great and they're an excellent way to learn more about how your radio works. FT8 has two main requirements:
texts.text: Digital modes are great and they're an excellent way to learn more about how your radio works. FT8 has two main requirements:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: A radio that can transmit single sideband (SSB).
texts.text: A radio that can transmit single sideband (SSB).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: A radio with sound input and output.
texts.text: A radio with sound input and output.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be sure to find an all-mode transceiver (discussion on that above) that has some type of audio or control interface. On my old Icom 746, there is a small remote connector on the back so the computer can control the radio itself. There is also an unusual 8-pin accessory plug that handles audio input and output. (I use an awesome sound card cable from  xggcomms  to transmit audio into my Icom.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Newer radios have a USB port right there on the back with audio and radio control built in! The  Icom 7300  has this feature and it works extremely well. All you need is a cheap USB cable that you can buy anywhere. The audio drivers show up just fine in Linux!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be sure to connect your audio via USB or some kind of accessory port. Some radios have microphone ports on the front, but that doesn't work well with FT8. Speech processing, auto gain control, and other fancy features that work wonders for voice transmissions can cause problems for FT8.
